title.value: Pontomedullary junction as a reference for spinal cord cross-sectional area: validation across neck positions
title.justification: Extracted directly from the title of the research paper
title.quote: Pontomedullary junction as a reference for spinal cord cross-sectional area: validation across neck positions

extractions.description: The paper validates the use of the Pontomedullary Junction (PMJ) as a reference point for measuring spinal cord cross-sectional area (CSA) across different neck positions using MRI. It compares the variability and reliability of CSA measurements using PMJ-based methods against traditional vertebral level-based references.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments with human participants to compare different methods of measuring spinal cord CSA using MRI.
type.quote: The goal of this study was to determine if the variability of CSA across neck flexions/extensions is reduced when using the PMJ, compared to vertebral levels. Ten participants underwent a 3T MRI T2w isotropic scan at 0.6 ­mm3 for 3 neck positions: extension, neutral and flexion.

name.justification: The study uses MRI to measure spinal cord cross-sectional area and involves validating imaging methods.
name.quote: Spinal cord cross-sectional area (CSA) is an important MRI biomarker to assess spinal cord atrophy in various neurodegenerative and traumatic spinal cord diseases.

name.justification: The paper specifically focuses on imaging the spinal cord, a part of the central nervous system, to assess its cross-sectional area.
name.quote: Spinal cord (SC) cross-sectional area (CSA) is a relevant biomarker to assess SC atrophy in diseases like multiple sclerosis (MS) and spinal cord injury.

name.justification: The study involves computational methods for segmenting MRI data of the spinal cord and processing the images to extract relevant metrics.
name.quote: The SC was automatically segmented using the Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT) v5.4 sct_deepseg_sc and the PMJ and vertebral levels were identified.

name.justification: The model was specifically mentioned as being used for automatic segmentation of the spinal cord in MRI images.
name.quote: The SC was automatically segmented using the Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT) v5.4 sct_deepseg_sc and the PMJ and vertebral levels were identified.

is_contributed.justification: The model was used in the research but was not introduced as a new model by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: The SC was automatically segmented using the Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT) v5.4 sct_deepseg_sc

is_executed.justification: The model was executed to perform automatic segmentation of MRI images of the spinal cord.
is_executed.quote: The SC was automatically segmented using the Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT) v5.4 sct_deepseg_sc

is_compared.justification: The focus of the paper is on the validation of CSA measurements rather than comparing different segmentation models.
is_compared.quote: Mean coefficient of variation for CSA across neck positions was 3.99 ± 2.96% for the PMJ method vs. 4.02 ± 3.01% for manual spinal segment method vs. 4.46 ± 3.10% for the disc method.

referenced_paper_title.value: Automatic segmentation of the spinal cord and intramedullary multiple sclerosis lesions with convolutional neural networks
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper likely provides the details and validation of the sct_deepseg_sc model used for spinal cord segmentation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Gros, C. et al. Automatic segmentation of the spinal cord and intramedullary multiple sclerosis lesions with convolutional neural networks. Neuroimage 184, 901–915 (2019).

name.justification: The dataset was explicitly mentioned as being used for the experiments in this study and is available publicly.
name.quote: All data is accessible on OpenNeuro in the BIDS format; manually corrected segmentations and PMJ, disc and spinal segment labels are also available: https://openn euro.ds004 507version1.0.1.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper likely provides the details of the Spinal Cord Head Position MRI dataset used in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Bédard, S. & Cohen-Adad, J. PMJ BIDS Dataset. (2023) doi:10.18112/OPENNEURO.DS004507.V1.0.1

name.justification: The library was specifically mentioned as being used for spinal cord segmentation and processing MRI data.
name.quote: The SC was automatically segmented using the Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT) v5.4 sct_deepseg_sc and the PMJ and vertebral levels were identified.

referenced_paper_title.value: SCT: Spinal cord toolbox, an open-source software for processing spinal cord MRI data
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper likely provides the details and validation of the Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT) used in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: De Leener, B. et al. SCT: Spinal cord toolbox, an open-source software for processing spinal cord MRI data. Neuroimage 145, 24–43 (2017).
